gr.forth.ics.graph.path
Interface Path

All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractPath
public interface Path

An immutable path, representing a continuous trail from a node to another node, moving through edges and nodes alternatively. Edges may be used opposite to their direction in a path. For example, assume nodes N1, N2, N3 and edges [N1-->N2], [N3-->N2]. These edges may form a path with this structure: [N1-->N2<--N3].

Returns the number of the node-to-node steps that are included in this path.

edgeCount

int edgeCount()
Returns the number of edges included in this path. This is equivalent to size(), since each edge defines a node-to-node step.

Returns:
the number of edges included in this path

int nodeCount()
Returns the number of nodes included in this path. This is equivalent to size() + 1.

the number of nodes included in this path

ExtendedIterable<Path> steps()
Returns an iterable of all subpaths of with size() == 1 of this path.

Returns:
an iterable of all the single-step subpaths of this path

nodes

ExtendedIterable<Node> nodes()
Returns an iterable that iterates this path's nodes. The first node is the #headNode() and the last is the #tailNode().

Returns:
an iterable that iterates this path's nodes

edges

ExtendedIterable<Edge> edges()
Returns an iterable that iterates this path's edges. The first edge (if exists) is the #headEdge() and the last (if exists) is the #tailEdge()

Returns:
an iterable that iterates this path's edges

getNode

Node getNode(int index)
Returns the specified node of this path. Valid node indexes are [-(nodeCount)..nodeCount - 1]. Zero index means the first node (the headNode()). Positive values denote the path steps from the head needed to get to the requested node, while negatives are translated to positives by adding nodeCount, i.e. -1 means the tail node, -2 the node before that, etc.

Parameters:
index - the index of the path node to return
Returns:
the node corresponding to the specified index

getEdge

Edge getEdge(int index)
Returns the specified edge of this path. Valid edge indexes are [-(edgeCount)..edgeCount - 1]. Zero index means the first edge(headEdge()). Positive values denote the path steps from the head needed to get to the requested node, while negatives are translated to positives by adding nodeCount, i.e. -1 means the last edge (headEdge()), -2 the edge before that, etc.

Parameters:
index - the index of the path edge to return
Returns:
the edge corresponding to the specified index

slice

Path slice(int start,
           int end)
Returns a path that starts at getNode(start) and ends at getNode(end). So, the resulting path has exactly end - start size. If start == end, then the resulting path consists of a single node. Valid node indexes are [0..nodeCount() - 1].

Parameters:
start - the node index from which the returned path starts
end - the node index to which the returned path ends
Returns:
a path that starts at getNode(start) and ends at getNode(end)
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - when start > end or start < 0 or end >= nodeCount()

headPath

Path headPath(int steps)
Returns a path that starts at the start of this path, and continues for the specified number of steps along this path. Valid step indexes are [0... edgeCount() - 1].

Parameters:
steps - the number of steps of this path that the returned path should have
Returns:
a path with the specified number of steps from the head of this path
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - when specified steps > size()

tailPath

Path tailPath(int steps)
Returns a path that ends to the end of this path, and continues backwards for the specified number of steps along this path. Valid step indexes are [0... edgeCount() - 1].

Parameters:
steps - the number of steps of this path that the returned path should have
Returns:
a path with the specified number of steps from the tail of this path
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - when specified steps > size()

split

Path[] split(int position)
Splits this path at a certain point and returns the two parts. This position denotes the index of the tailNode() of the first path, and the headNode() of the second path. Valid position indexes are [0... nodeCount() - 1].

Parameters:
position - the position of the node (getNode(position)) that the first path will end to and the second path will begin from
Returns:
an array with the two splitted paths
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if position is not a valid node index

append

Path append(Path other)
Returns a path that is produced by appending the given path at the tail of this path. The two paths must be consecutive, that is, other.headNode() == this.tailNode().

Returns:
a path that is produced by appending the given path at the tail of this path
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if other.headNode() != this.tailNode()

isCycle

boolean isCycle()
Returns true if headNode() == tailNode(), that is, if the path starts and ends at the same node, unless the path is a single node, when conventionally it is not considered a cycle.

Returns:
whether this path is a cycle

replaceFirst

Path replaceFirst(Path subpath,
                  Path replacement)
Returns a path that is produced by exchanging the first occurence of the given subpath, in this path, with the given replacement. The subpath and the replacement must start and end on the same nodes respectively. There is an exception though: if the subpath lies at the start or at the end of this path, then the replacement needs not start or end and the same node respectively. Thus, in this cases the replacement can be used to create a path that either starts at a different node than this path, or ends in a different node.

If the subpath is not contained in this path, nothing happens.

Examples, assuming this path is [1-->2-->3-->4]:

  • if subpath is [2-->3], then the replacement must start on [2] and end on [3] (with whatever length)
  • if subpath is [1-->2], then the replacement path only needs to end at [2], for example this replacement is fine: [A-->B-->C-->2], which would yield: [A-->B-->C-->2-->3-->4]
  • if subpath is [3-->4], then the replacement path only needs to start at [3], for example this replacement if fine: [3-->X-->Y--Z], which would yield: [1-->2-->3-->X-->Y-->Z]

Returns:
a path resulted from replacing the specified subpath with the replacement
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the replacement is illegal, in the sense that would produce a non-continuous path

replace

Path replace(int start,
             int end,
             Path replacement)
Returns a path by replacing the specified subpath (described as a slice) with a replacement. Parameters start and end describe the head and tail node of the subpath to be replaced. Valid node indexes are [0... nodeCount() - 1]. Applying the replacement must produce a continuous path, i.e. its head and tail node must match the head and tail node of the subpath, unless either is the head or tail of this path. See replaceFirst(Path, Path) for more details.

Parameters:
start - the index of the head node of the subpath
end - the index of the end node of the subpath
Returns:
a path by replacing the specified subpath with a replacement
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the indexes are invalid
See Also:
replaceFirst(Path, Path)

replaceAll

Path replaceAll(Path subpath,
                Path replacement)
Returns a path that is produces by replacing every occurrence of the specified subpath in this path, by the specified replacement. The replacement's head and tail nodes must match the head and tail nodes of the subpath, respectively.

Parameters:
subpath - the subpath occurrences of which to replace with another path
replacement - the path with which to replace all occurrences of subpath
Returns:
the resulting path
See Also:
replaceFirst(Path, Path)

contains

boolean contains(Path subpath)
Returns whether the specified path occurs in this path. This is equivalent to find(path) != -1.

Parameters:
subpath - the subpath to search in this path
Returns:
whether the specified path occurs in this path

find

int find(Path subpath)
Searches for the given subpath in this path. If a match is found, the index of its first node in this path is returned. If no match is found, -1 is returned.

Parameters:
subpath - the subpath to search in this path
Returns:
the index of the node where a match starts, or -1 is no match was found

find

int find(Path path,
         int from)
Searches for the given subpath in this path, starting at the specified node index and continuing towards the tail. If a match is found, the index of its first node in this path is returned. If no match is found, -1 is returned.

Parameters:
path - the subpath to search in this path
from - the index of the node to start the search, and continue towards the tail
Returns:
the index of the node where a match starts, or -1 is no match was found

reverse

Path reverse()
Returns a path that is the reverse of this path.

Returns:
a path that is the reverse of this path
